canonical_explanation.text: Polymers are high molecular mass macromolecules formed by the linking of a large number of small repeating units called monomers through a process called polymerisation. Classification of polymers can be based on several criteria. Based on source: natural polymers (proteins, cellulose, natural rubber, starch), semi-synthetic polymers (cellulose acetate, cellulose nitrate, vulcanised rubber), and synthetic polymers (polythene, nylon, Bakelite, PVC). Based on structure: linear polymers (HDPE, HDP, PVC) have long straight chains; branched chain polymers (LDPE, low-density polythene) have branches along the main chain; and cross-linked or network polymers (Bakelite, melamine-formaldehyde) have monomers linked together forming a three-dimensional network. Based on mode of polymerisation: addition polymers are formed by repeated addition of monomers with double bonds without loss of any molecule (e.g., polythene, polypropylene, PVC, polystyrene, Teflon, polyacrylonitrile); condensation polymers are formed by the reaction of bifunctional or polyfunctional monomers with the elimination of small molecules like water (e.g., nylon 6,6; nylon 6; polyester/Terylene/Dacron; Bakelite; melamine-formaldehyde). Based on molecular forces: elastomers have weak intermolecular forces and can be stretched (rubber, Buna-S, Buna-N, neoprene); fibres have strong intermolecular forces (hydrogen bonds) and high tensile strength (nylon, polyester, silk); thermoplastics soften on heating and can be remoulded repeatedly (polythene, PVC, polystyrene); thermosetting plastics undergo permanent change on heating due to cross-linking and cannot be remoulded (Bakelite, urea-formaldehyde resin). Addition polymerisation involves chain-growth mechanism with free radical, cationic, or anionic initiators. Free radical polymerisation of ethene uses benzoyl peroxide as initiator: initiation (generation of free radical), propagation (radical adds to monomer), and termination (two radicals combine). Important addition polymers: polythene (LDPE at 1000-2000 atm with O2 trace; HDPE using Ziegler-Natta catalyst at low pressure), polypropylene, polystyrene, PVC, Teflon (PTFE), polyacrylonitrile (orlon/acrilan). Copolymerisation forms polymers from two or more monomers: Buna-S (butadiene + styrene), Buna-N (butadiene + acrylonitrile). Condensation polymerisation (step-growth): nylon 6,6 is formed from hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid; nylon 6 from caprolactam; polyester (Terylene) from ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid; Bakelite from phenol and formaldehyde (novolac then cross-linked); melamine-formaldehyde resin from melamine and formaldehyde. Natural rubber is cis-1,4-polyisoprene. Vulcanisation (heating rubber with sulphur) introduces cross-links that improve strength, elasticity and resistance. Synthetic rubbers: neoprene (polychloroprene) and Buna rubbers. Biodegradable polymers include PHBV (poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate-co-beta-hydroxyvalerate) and nylon 2-nylon 6 (polyglycine/polyaminocaproic acid). Commercially important polymers include polycarbonates, polyurethanes, and silicone polymers.
rules: Polymers are classified by source (natural, semi-synthetic, synthetic), structure (linear, branched, cross-linked), polymerisation mode (addition, condensation), and molecular forces (elastomers, fibres, thermoplastics, thermosetting).
Addition polymers form by chain-growth from unsaturated monomers without loss of atoms; condensation polymers form by step-growth with elimination of small molecules (usually water).
Free radical polymerisation has three steps: initiation (radical generation), propagation (chain growth), and termination (radical combination).
LDPE is formed at high pressure with trace O2; HDPE is formed at low pressure with Ziegler-Natta catalyst (TiCl4 + Al(C2H5)3).
Nylon 6,6 is a condensation polymer of hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid; nylon 6 is formed by ring-opening polymerisation of caprolactam.
Bakelite is a cross-linked polymer of phenol and formaldehyde; it is thermosetting and cannot be remoulded once set.
Natural rubber is cis-1,4-polyisoprene; vulcanisation with sulphur introduces cross-links improving elasticity and strength.
Thermoplastics can be remoulded repeatedly on heating; thermosetting plastics undergo irreversible cross-linking on heating.
PHBV (poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate-co-beta-hydroxyvalerate) is a biodegradable polymer used in packaging and orthopaedic devices.
Copolymers contain two or more different monomers: Buna-S (butadiene + styrene) and Buna-N (butadiene + acrylonitrile) are synthetic rubbers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a natural polymer?
questions.explanation_correct: Cellulose is a natural polymer composed of glucose monomers linked by glycosidic bonds. It is found in plant cell walls and is the most abundant organic polymer on Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon 6,6, polythene, and PVC are all synthetic polymers made through chemical polymerisation processes in industry.

questions.question_text: A polymer that softens on heating and can be remoulded repeatedly is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Thermoplastics soften on heating and harden on cooling. They can be remoulded repeatedly without significant chemical change because they have linear or slightly branched chains held by weak intermolecular forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermosetting plastics undergo irreversible cross-linking on heating and cannot be remoulded. Elastomers are stretchable. Fibres have high tensile strength.

questions.question_text: Which classification of polymers is based on intermolecular forces?
questions.explanation_correct: Classification into elastomers, fibres, thermoplastics, and thermosetting plastics is based on the type and strength of intermolecular forces between polymer chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Addition/condensation is based on polymerisation mode. Linear/branched/cross-linked is based on structure. Natural/semi-synthetic/synthetic is based on source.

questions.question_text: Cellulose acetate (rayon) is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Cellulose acetate is a semi-synthetic polymer because it is prepared by chemical modification (acetylation) of a natural polymer (cellulose). It retains the cellulose backbone but with chemically altered groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not natural because it has been chemically modified, and not fully synthetic since the backbone is derived from natural cellulose.

questions.question_text: Low density polythene (LDPE) has a branched structure. This results in:

options.text: Higher density and greater hardness than HDPE
Lower density and lower melting point than HDPE

questions.explanation_correct: Branching in LDPE prevents close packing of polymer chains, resulting in lower density, lower crystallinity, and a lower melting point compared to linear HDPE where chains pack tightly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LDPE has lower density, not higher. LDPE and HDPE have different properties due to structural differences. LDPE is branched, not cross-linked.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a thermosetting polymer?
questions.explanation_correct: Bakelite is a thermosetting polymer formed by cross-linking phenol-formaldehyde resin. Once set by heating, the extensive cross-links make it rigid and infusible; it cannot be remoulded.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polythene, PVC, and polystyrene are all thermoplastics that can be softened by heating and remoulded repeatedly.

questions.question_text: Fibres have high tensile strength because they have:

options.text: Very weak van der Waals forces

questions.explanation_correct: Fibres like nylon and polyester have strong intermolecular forces, particularly hydrogen bonds (in nylon) and dipole-dipole interactions, which hold the chains tightly together, giving high tensile strength and high melting points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weak van der Waals forces would give elastomeric properties. Cross-linking gives thermosetting character. Branching reduces chain packing and strength.

questions.question_text: Match the polymer with its correct classification: Nylon 6,6 is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 6,6 is formed by condensation of hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid (condensation polymer), can be melted and remoulded (thermoplastic), and has strong intermolecular H-bonds giving high tensile strength (fibre).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon 6,6 is not an addition polymer (it eliminates water). It is not thermosetting (it can be melted). It is not an elastomer (it is rigid and strong).

questions.question_text: An elastomer can be stretched because it has:

options.text: Weak intermolecular forces with coiled chains that can uncoil on stretching
A purely linear chain with no branching

questions.explanation_correct: Elastomers have weak van der Waals forces between polymer chains. The chains adopt a coiled or randomly tangled conformation. When stretched, the coils straighten out, and when released, they return to the coiled state (elastic behaviour).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Strong H-bonds are characteristic of fibres. Three-dimensional networks describe thermosetting plastics. Purely linear chains with strong forces would form fibres, not elastomers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following polymers has a cross-linked or network structure?
questions.explanation_correct: Melamine-formaldehyde resin is a cross-linked (network) polymer. Melamine has three -NH2 groups that react with formaldehyde to form a three-dimensional network structure, making it thermosetting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HDPE is linear, LDPE is branched, and PVC is essentially linear. None of these has a true cross-linked network structure.

questions.question_text: In addition polymerisation, the polymer is formed by:

options.text: Repeated addition of monomers with elimination of water
Repeated addition of monomers with no loss of atoms

questions.explanation_correct: In addition (chain-growth) polymerisation, monomers with double bonds add to each other repeatedly without the loss of any atoms. The molecular formula of the repeating unit is the same as the monomer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elimination of water occurs in condensation polymerisation. Ring-opening is a specific type that does not apply to all addition polymers. Cross-linking is a structural modification, not a polymerisation type.

questions.question_text: The monomer of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is:
questions.explanation_correct: PVC (polyvinyl chloride) is formed by addition polymerisation of vinyl chloride (chloroethene, CH2=CHCl). The Cl atom remains on every other carbon in the polymer chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethene gives polyethylene, styrene gives polystyrene, and propene gives polypropylene. Each monomer gives a distinct polymer.

questions.question_text: Nylon 6,6 is formed by the condensation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 6,6 is formed by condensation polymerisation of hexamethylenediamine (H2N-(CH2)6-NH2) and adipic acid (HOOC-(CH2)4-COOH), with elimination of water. The name 6,6 refers to the six carbons in each monomer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Caprolactam gives nylon 6. Ethylene glycol + terephthalic acid gives Terylene/PET. Phenol + formaldehyde gives Bakelite.

questions.question_text: The three steps in free radical polymerisation are:
questions.explanation_correct: Free radical polymerisation proceeds in three steps: initiation (free radical is generated from an initiator like benzoyl peroxide), propagation (radical attacks monomer creating a new radical, chain grows), and termination (two radicals combine to end the chain).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options describe different types of chemical reactions, not the mechanism of polymerisation.

questions.question_text: Teflon (PTFE) is formed by the polymerisation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Teflon (polytetrafluoroethylene, PTFE) is formed by addition polymerisation of tetrafluoroethylene (CF2=CF2). The strong C-F bonds make Teflon chemically inert and non-stick.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethylene gives polythene, vinyl chloride gives PVC, and acrylonitrile gives polyacrylonitrile (orlon). Only CF2=CF2 gives Teflon.

questions.question_text: Terylene (Dacron) is a condensation polymer of:
questions.explanation_correct: Terylene (also called Dacron or PET) is a polyester formed by condensation of ethylene glycol (HOCH2CH2OH) and terephthalic acid (para-C6H4(COOH)2) with elimination of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hexamethylenediamine + sebacic acid gives nylon 6,10. Phenol + formaldehyde gives Bakelite. Melamine + formaldehyde gives melamine resin.

questions.question_text: The catalyst used for the preparation of HDPE (high density polyethylene) is:
questions.explanation_correct: HDPE is prepared by polymerisation of ethylene at low pressure (6-7 atm) and moderate temperature (60-70 degree C) using Ziegler-Natta catalyst (TiCl4 + triethylaluminium). This gives a linear, high-density polymer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzoyl peroxide is used as initiator for LDPE (high pressure process). H2SO4 is not used for polymerisation. V2O5 is used in contact process for H2SO4 manufacture.

questions.question_text: Nylon 6 is obtained by:

options.text: Condensation of hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid

questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 6 is formed by ring-opening polymerisation of caprolactam (a 7-membered ring lactam with 6 carbon atoms). The ring opens and the units join by amide bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hexamethylenediamine + adipic acid gives nylon 6,6 (not nylon 6). Acrylonitrile gives polyacrylonitrile. Phenol + formaldehyde gives Bakelite.

questions.question_text: Bakelite is formed in multiple steps. The initial product of reaction between phenol and formaldehyde is:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol + formaldehyde first forms novolac (a linear polymer) when phenol is in excess under acidic conditions. Novolac is then heated with more formaldehyde and a cross-linking agent to form Bakelite.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cross-linked Bakelite is the final product, not the initial one. Ortho-hydroxymethylphenol may be an initial adduct but novolac is the first polymeric product. Bakelite is not formed directly.

questions.question_text: Buna-S is a copolymer of:
questions.explanation_correct: Buna-S (styrene-butadiene rubber, SBR) is a copolymer of 1,3-butadiene (Bu for butadiene, Na for sodium catalyst) and styrene (S). It is widely used as a synthetic rubber.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1,3-butadiene + acrylonitrile gives Buna-N. Isoprene polymerises to form synthetic natural rubber. Chloroprene gives neoprene.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an addition polymer?
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 6,6 is a condensation polymer formed from hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid with elimination of water. All the others (polystyrene, Teflon, polyacrylonitrile) are addition polymers formed from unsaturated monomers without loss of atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polystyrene (from styrene), Teflon (from CF2=CF2), and polyacrylonitrile (from CH2=CHCN) are all addition polymers.

questions.question_text: The initiator commonly used in free radical polymerisation of ethylene is:
questions.explanation_correct: Benzoyl peroxide ((C6H5COO)2) is a common free radical initiator. It decomposes on heating to generate free radicals (C6H5COO* then C6H5*) that initiate the chain polymerisation of ethylene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BF3 is a Lewis acid used in cationic polymerisation. AlCl3 is a Friedel-Crafts catalyst. NaOH is a base used in other reactions. Only benzoyl peroxide generates free radicals for radical polymerisation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes condensation polymerisation correctly?

options.text: Monomers must have C=C double bonds
Bifunctional or polyfunctional monomers react with loss of small molecules like water
It always requires a free radical initiator
The polymer has the same empirical formula as the monomer

questions.explanation_correct: In condensation polymerisation, bifunctional or polyfunctional monomers (with -OH, -COOH, -NH2 groups) react with each other, and a small molecule (usually water) is eliminated in each step.
questions.explanation_incorrect: C=C double bonds are needed for addition polymerisation. Free radical initiators are for addition polymerisation. In condensation, the polymer has a different empirical formula because atoms are lost as water.

questions.question_text: Melamine-formaldehyde polymer is used to make unbreakable crockery because it is:

options.text: A linear thermoplastic that can absorb shock
A highly cross-linked, thermosetting polymer that is hard and heat-resistant
A fibre with high tensile strength

questions.explanation_correct: Melamine (which has three -NH2 groups) reacts with formaldehyde to form a highly cross-linked three-dimensional network. This thermosetting polymer is extremely hard, heat-resistant, and scratch-resistant, making it ideal for crockery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not thermoplastic (it cannot be remoulded). It is not an elastomer or fibre. Its hardness and heat resistance come from extensive cross-linking.

questions.question_text: The linkage present in polyesters like Terylene is:
questions.explanation_correct: Terylene (PET) is a polyester containing ester linkages (-COO-) formed by condensation between the -COOH groups of terephthalic acid and the -OH groups of ethylene glycol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amide linkages are found in nylons. Ether linkages are in polyethers. Glycosidic linkages are in polysaccharides like starch and cellulose.

questions.question_text: Natural rubber is a polymer of:
questions.explanation_correct: Natural rubber is cis-1,4-polyisoprene, formed from isoprene (2-methyl-1,3-butadiene, CH2=C(CH3)-CH=CH2) monomers linked in the cis configuration at the double bond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chloroprene gives neoprene (synthetic rubber). Styrene gives polystyrene. Ethylene gives polythene.

questions.question_text: Vulcanisation of rubber involves heating natural rubber with:
questions.explanation_correct: Vulcanisation involves heating natural rubber with sulphur (about 5% S). Sulphur forms cross-links (S-S bridges) between polymer chains, improving elasticity, strength, and resistance to temperature and solvents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen causes degradation (ageing) of rubber. Nitrogen is inert. Chlorine would cause halogenation. Only sulphur provides the desired cross-linking.

questions.question_text: Neoprene is a synthetic rubber obtained by polymerisation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Neoprene (polychloroprene) is formed by addition polymerisation of chloroprene (2-chloro-1,3-butadiene, CH2=CCl-CH=CH2). It is resistant to oils, heat, and chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isoprene gives natural rubber. 1,3-Butadiene gives polybutadiene or is used in copolymers. Acrylonitrile gives polyacrylonitrile or is used in Buna-N.

questions.question_text: PHBV is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: PHBV (poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate-co-beta-hydroxyvalerate) is a biodegradable polymer that can be broken down by microorganisms in the environment. It is used in packaging and in medical applications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PHBV is not thermosetting, conducting, or inorganic. Its primary significance is its biodegradability.

questions.question_text: The configuration of natural rubber at the double bond is:

options.text: Both cis and trans in equal amounts

questions.explanation_correct: Natural rubber is cis-1,4-polyisoprene. The cis configuration means the polymer chain continues on the same side of the double bond. Gutta-percha is the trans isomer, which is harder and less elastic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trans-polyisoprene is gutta-percha, not natural rubber. Natural rubber specifically has cis configuration which gives it elasticity. Double bonds are present in the polymer backbone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used in making non-stick cookware (Teflon-coated pans)?
questions.explanation_correct: PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene, Teflon) is used for non-stick cookware coatings. The strong C-F bonds make it chemically inert, heat-resistant, and give it an extremely low coefficient of friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PVC is used for pipes and insulation. Polystyrene is used for packaging. Bakelite is used for electrical switches. Only Teflon has the non-stick properties required.

questions.question_text: Vulcanisation improves which property of natural rubber?

options.text: Makes it softer and more sticky
Improves elasticity, tensile strength, and resistance to oxidation
Makes it soluble in organic solvents

questions.explanation_correct: Vulcanisation introduces sulphur cross-links between rubber chains, which improves elasticity, tensile strength, hardness, and resistance to heat, oxidation, and organic solvents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vulcanised rubber is less sticky and less soluble in solvents (due to cross-links). It remains an elastomer, not a thermoplastic.

questions.question_text: Buna-N rubber has good resistance to oils because it contains:
questions.explanation_correct: Buna-N (nitrile rubber) is a copolymer of 1,3-butadiene and acrylonitrile. The polar -CN groups in acrylonitrile units give the rubber resistance to non-polar oils and fuels due to the principle 'like dissolves like'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Styrene units are in Buna-S. Chlorine atoms are in neoprene. Fluorine atoms are in Teflon. The oil resistance of Buna-N comes from its polar nitrile groups.

questions.question_text: Which polymer is commonly used in making plastic bottles for carbonated drinks?
questions.explanation_correct: PET (polyethylene terephthalate, same as Terylene/Dacron) is widely used for carbonated drink bottles due to its transparency, strength, gas barrier properties, and light weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PVC has health concerns and is used for pipes. HDPE is used for milk containers and rigid packaging. Polystyrene is used for foam packaging and cups.

questions.question_text: The polymer nylon 2-nylon 6 is an alternating copolymer of glycine and aminocaproic acid. It is significant because it is:

options.text: A natural polymer found in silk

questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 2-nylon 6 is a polyamide that is biodegradable because it resembles proteins (polyamino acids). The amide bonds can be broken down by enzymes in the environment, unlike conventional nylon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not the strongest fibre, not used in Teflon, and not a natural polymer. Its significance lies in its biodegradability.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents correct matching? (I) Linear polymer - HDPE, (II) Branched polymer - LDPE, (III) Cross-linked polymer - Bakelite

options.text: All I, II, and III are correct

questions.explanation_correct: HDPE is linear (chains pack closely, high density), LDPE is branched (branches prevent close packing, low density), and Bakelite is cross-linked (phenol-formaldehyde network). All three matchings are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three matchings are factually correct. HDPE is indeed linear, LDPE is branched, and Bakelite has a cross-linked network structure.

questions.question_text: Polyacrylonitrile is used to make synthetic fibres known as:
questions.explanation_correct: Polyacrylonitrile (PAN), formed from acrylonitrile (CH2=CHCN), is used to make acrylic fibres commercially known as Orlon or Acrilan. These fibres are used as wool substitutes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dacron is polyester (PET). Rayon is regenerated cellulose. Nylon is a polyamide. Orlon/Acrilan is the acrylic fibre from polyacrylonitrile.

questions.question_text: Polythene bags are an environmental concern because they are:

options.text: Non-biodegradable and persist in the environment

questions.explanation_correct: Polythene is non-biodegradable - microorganisms cannot break it down. It persists in the environment for hundreds of years, clogging drains, harming wildlife, and polluting soil and water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polythene is chemically inert (not reactive with soil), non-toxic to touch, and not radioactive. Its environmental problem is its persistence due to non-biodegradability.

questions.question_text: Gutta-percha differs from natural rubber because:

options.text: It is an addition polymer while rubber is a condensation polymer
It has trans configuration at the double bonds while rubber has cis
It is a copolymer while rubber is a homopolymer
It contains chlorine while rubber does not

questions.explanation_correct: Both gutta-percha and natural rubber are polyisoprene, but gutta-percha has trans-1,4 configuration while natural rubber has cis-1,4 configuration. This makes gutta-percha harder, less elastic, and more crystalline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both are addition polymers from the same monomer (isoprene). Neither is a copolymer. Neither contains chlorine. The only difference is the cis/trans configuration.

questions.question_text: A polymer that cannot be remoulded once set, because of extensive cross-linking, is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Thermosetting polymers undergo irreversible chemical change (cross-linking) when heated. Once cross-linked, they form a rigid three-dimensional network that cannot be softened or remoulded.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thermoplastics can be remoulded. Elastomers are stretchable. Fibres have high tensile strength but can be melted. Only thermosetting plastics are permanently set after initial moulding.

questions.question_text: Polypropylene is obtained by addition polymerisation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Polypropylene is formed by addition polymerisation of propylene (propene, CH2=CHCH3). It is a tough, rigid thermoplastic used in packaging, textiles, and automotive parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethylene gives polyethylene, butadiene gives polybutadiene, and vinyl chloride gives PVC.

questions.question_text: During the termination step of free radical polymerisation, what happens?

options.text: The growing chain radical adds another monomer
Two growing chain radicals combine or disproportionate, ending chain growth
The monomer is converted to a different isomer

questions.explanation_correct: In the termination step, two growing polymer chain radicals combine (coupling) or transfer hydrogen (disproportionation), destroying the radical centres and stopping chain growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radical generation is initiation. Adding monomers is propagation. Isomerisation is not a step in polymerisation. Termination specifically involves destruction of radical centres.

questions.question_text: Which of the following commercial polymers is used for making electrical insulation and pipes?
questions.explanation_correct: PVC (polyvinyl chloride) is widely used for electrical wire insulation, water pipes, and floor tiles due to its good insulating properties, chemical resistance, and durability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polystyrene is used for packaging and disposable items. Nylon 6,6 is used for fibres and gears. Natural rubber is used for tyres and elastic products.

questions.question_text: Silicone polymers have a backbone of alternating:
questions.explanation_correct: Silicone polymers (polysiloxanes) have an inorganic backbone of alternating silicon and oxygen atoms (-Si-O-Si-O-), with organic groups (usually methyl) attached to silicon. They are heat-resistant and biocompatible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon-nitrogen forms polyamides. Carbon-carbon is the backbone of addition polymers like polythene. Silicon-carbon does not form the silicone backbone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a synthetic polymer?
questions.explanation_correct: Starch is a natural polymer composed of amylose and amylopectin (both made of glucose units). It is produced by plants for energy storage, not synthesised in a laboratory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nylon, polythene, and Teflon are all synthetic polymers manufactured by chemical processes.

questions.question_text: The linkage present in nylon 6,6 between monomer units is:
questions.explanation_correct: Nylon 6,6 is a polyamide. The -COOH group of adipic acid reacts with the -NH2 group of hexamethylenediamine to form amide linkages (-CONH-) with elimination of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ester linkages are in polyesters. Ether linkages are in polyethers. Carbon-carbon bonds link monomers in addition polymers. Nylon specifically has amide bonds.

questions.question_text: Which property makes natural rubber unsuitable for many applications without vulcanisation?

options.text: It is too hard and brittle
It becomes sticky in heat and brittle in cold
It is insoluble in all solvents

questions.explanation_correct: Unvulcanised natural rubber becomes soft and sticky in hot weather and hard and brittle in cold weather. Vulcanisation with sulphur introduces cross-links that solve these problems by maintaining consistent elasticity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural rubber is not hard/brittle at room temperature; it is too soft. It is soluble in many organic solvents (which vulcanisation helps prevent). It does not conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: Proteins are natural polymers. The monomer units of proteins are:
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are condensation polymers of alpha-amino acids linked by peptide bonds (-CONH-). There are 20 naturally occurring amino acids that serve as monomers for protein synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nucleotides are monomers of nucleic acids (DNA, RNA). Glucose is the monomer of polysaccharides like starch. Fatty acids are components of fats/lipids, not polymers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following polymers is used in making bulletproof vests?
questions.explanation_correct: Kevlar is an aromatic polyamide (aramid) with extremely high tensile strength, about five times stronger than steel on a weight basis. It is used in bulletproof vests, helmets, and aerospace applications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polystyrene is a brittle thermoplastic. LDPE is flexible and weak. Natural rubber is elastic. None of these has the extreme tensile strength needed for body armour.

questions.question_text: What distinguishes a copolymer from a homopolymer?

options.text: A copolymer is always natural while a homopolymer is synthetic
A copolymer is formed from two or more different monomers, while a homopolymer uses only one type of monomer
A copolymer is always cross-linked while a homopolymer is linear
A copolymer has lower molecular mass than a homopolymer

questions.explanation_correct: A copolymer is formed by polymerisation of two or more different types of monomers (e.g., Buna-S from butadiene + styrene), while a homopolymer is formed from only one type of monomer (e.g., polythene from ethylene only).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both copolymers and homopolymers can be synthetic. Copolymers can be linear or branched. Molecular mass is not the distinguishing factor.
